ud5.3:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ud5.3:1.3: At that time in Rājagaha there was a leper called Suppabuddha.
ud5.3:1.4: He was poor, destitute, and pitiful.
ud5.3:1.5: Now, at that time the Buddha was teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.
ud5.3:2.1: Suppabuddha saw the crowd seated off in the distance
ud5.3:2.3: “Surely some variety of foods will be distributed there.
ud5.3:2.4: Why don’t I approach the crowd?
ud5.3:2.5: Hopefully I’ll get something to eat.”
ud5.3:3.2: where he saw the Buddha teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.
ud5.3:3.3: When he saw this he thought,
ud5.3:3.5: The ascetic Gotama is teaching Dhamma in an assembly.
ud5.3:3.6: Why don’t I also listen to the teaching?”
ud5.3:3.7: Right there he sat down to one side, thinking,
ud5.3:3.8: “I also will listen to the teaching.”
ud5.3:4.1: Then the Buddha focused on comprehending the minds of everyone in the Saṅgha, thinking,
ud5.3:4.2: “Who here is capable of understanding the teaching?”
ud5.3:4.3: He saw Suppabuddha sitting in the assembly,
ud5.3:4.5: “He is capable of understanding the teaching.”
ud5.3:4.6: He gave a step by step talk especially for Suppabuddha
ud5.3:4.7: on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.
ud5.3:4.8: When the Buddha knew that Suppabuddha’s mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, elated, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:
ud5.3:4.9: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ud5.3:4.10: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,
ud5.3:4.11: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma in Suppabuddha:
ud5.3:4.12: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
ud5.3:5.1: Then Suppabuddha saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He rose from his seat and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:
ud5.3:6.2: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
ud5.3:6.3: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ud5.3:6.4: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ud5.3:7.1: After Suppabuddha had been educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.
ud5.3:7.2: But soon after Suppabuddha had left, a cow with a baby calf charged at him and took his life.
ud5.3:8.1: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said,
ud5.3:8.3: “The leper called Suppabuddha, after being educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, has passed away.
ud5.3:8.4: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
ud5.3:9.1: “Mendicants, Suppabuddha was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
ud5.3:9.2: With the ending of three fetters, Suppabuddha is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ud5.3:10.1: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,
ud5.3:10.2: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why Suppabuddha became a leper,
ud5.3:11.1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Suppabuddha used to be a financier’s son right here in Rājagaha.
ud5.3:11.2: On his way to visit a park, he saw Tagarasikhi, a Buddha awakened for themselves, entering the city for alms.
ud5.3:11.3: When he saw this he thought,
ud5.3:11.4: “Who is this leper wandering about with his leper’s robe?”
ud5.3:11.5: Before leaving, he spat on the ground and turned his left side to Tagarasikhi.
ud5.3:11.6: As a result of that deed he burned in hell for many years, for many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years.
ud5.3:11.7: And as a residual result of that same deed, he became a leper right here in Rājagaha, poor, destitute and pitiful.
ud5.3:11.8: But owing to faith in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, he undertook ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
ud5.3:11.9: After undertaking these things, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three.
ud5.3:11.10: There he outshines the other gods in beauty and glory.”
ud5.3:12.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud5.3:13.1: “As a well-sighted man would avoid rough paths,
ud5.3:13.2: so long as strength is found;
ud5.3:13.3: an astute person in the living world,
